Caspar Hauser
The Enigma of a Century
BY JACOB WASSERMANN
One of the finest and most important of Wassermann’s novels. Caspar Hauser
is a symbol; he is the human being, pure, undefiled—endowed with great natural
talents and almost superhuman sensitiveness. The story is laid against a vivid
panorama of Europe in the Nineteenth Century with an introduction written
especially for the American edition by the author. Caspar Hauser, that strange
figure which puzzled Europe when he first appeared, until he met his inexplicable
death, has remained an unsolved mystery to this day. $4.95
Seven Plays
BY ERNST TOLLER
(With an introduction by the Author)
Comprising, “The Machine-Wreckers,” “Transfiguration,” “Masses and Man,”
“Hinkemann,” “Hoppla! Such is Life,” “The Blind Goddess,” “Draw the Fires!”
and “Mary Baker Eddy”—each play is a serious reflection of a worthy and
intelligent dramatist on the impact which life had shaken him. Almost all
the plays cry out with what Toller thought to be an inadequate social system for
the working-class. $4.95
Alfred Adler
The Man and His Work
BY HERTHA ORGLER
Alfred Adler is best known for his discovery of the “inferiority complex”
and “individual psychology” the most fruitful approach to personality problems.
The author describes how Adler’s life and work were inter-related and makes
him live for her readers. The account of the “incurable burglar” who was cured
by Adler is spellbinding. A must for parents and teachers! $5.95
